issues.description: Users are forced to create an account and provide personal information before they can view available health insurance plans. This blocks exploratory browsing and violates the principle of flexibility by requiring commitment before providing value.
issues.evidence: NNg identified this as a major barrier: users must complete lengthy registration before seeing any plan options, causing high abandonment rates.

issues.element: Hero image pushing CTAs below the fold
issues.description: Primary call-to-action buttons are pushed below the visible viewport by a large hero image on the homepage. Users must scroll before they can see how to begin the enrollment process, reducing discoverability of the main action.
issues.evidence: Large hero banner dominates above-the-fold real estate, delaying user access to primary enrollment actions.

issues.element: Process illustration on Get Started page
issues.description: The Get Started page features a cryptic process illustration that fails to communicate the enrollment steps clearly. The abstract visual does not help users understand what to expect from the multi-step process.
issues.evidence: NNg noted the illustration was abstract and did not effectively communicate the enrollment workflow to new users.

issues.element: Non-standard progress indicator (3 dots in lower-left)
issues.description: The account creation flow uses a non-standard progress indicator consisting of three dots positioned in the lower-left corner. This deviates from conventional progress bar patterns and is easily overlooked, leaving users uncertain about how many steps remain.
issues.evidence: Progress indicator placement and style deviate from standard UI patterns, causing confusion about position in multi-step flow.

issues.element: Username input field with complex requirements
issues.description: The username field requires between 6 and 74 characters, an unusually wide and confusing range. This arbitrary constraint is not clearly communicated upfront and causes user errors during account creation.
issues.evidence: NNg flagged the 6-74 character requirement as unnecessarily complex and poorly communicated to users.

issues.element: Password input field with excessive constraints
issues.description: Password requirements include multiple simultaneous constraints (uppercase, lowercase, number, special character, minimum length) presented as a wall of rules. The excessive requirements increase cognitive load and cause repeated failed attempts.
issues.evidence: Multiple password rules displayed simultaneously create high error rates and frustration during signup.

issues.element: Error message text for form validation
issues.description: Error messages during account creation are vague and unhelpful, such as 'not a valid email' without specifying what is wrong. Users cannot determine how to fix their input from the error message alone.
issues.evidence: NNg specifically cited 'not a valid email' as an example of error messages that fail to guide users toward correction.

issues.description: The password field lacks a visibility toggle, preventing users from verifying their input before submission. This is especially problematic given the complex password requirements, as users cannot check for typos.
issues.evidence: Combined with strict password rules, the inability to see typed passwords compounds error rates.

issues.description: Users are required to answer security questions during the initial signup flow, adding unnecessary friction. These questions could be deferred to a later point without compromising security, reducing the barrier to entry.
issues.evidence: Security questions during signup add extra steps that increase abandonment without clear immediate benefit.

issues.element: Page content text across the site
issues.description: Site content is written at approximately a 9th-grade reading level, which exceeds the recommended 6th-8th grade level for government health information. This makes critical healthcare information harder to understand for low-literacy populations who most need the service.
issues.evidence: NNg analysis found reading level above recommended standards for government health services targeting general public.
